metadata.title: Biochar-templated g-C3N4/Bi2O2CO3/CoFe2O4 nano-assembly for visible and solar assisted photo-degradation of paraquat, nitrophenol reduction and CO2conversion

sections.text:
The development of novel visible powered nano-heterojunctions with multi-pronged capabilities for environmental and catalytic applications has been gaining importance for persistent pollutant degradation & clean energy production. A magnetically recoverable biochar supported ternary gC3N4/Bi2O2CO3/CoFe2O4 heterojunction (BCBF) was fabricated which shows a high visible photoactivity. The heterojunction was used for degradation of pesticide paraquat under visible radiation (Xe lamp), natural sunlight, photo-ozonation, peroxymonosulphate, and coupled conditions. A high degradation of 99.3% was achieved under visible radiation in 90 min and 92.1% under solar light in 120 min. Biochar supported ternary junction performs manifold faster than Bi2O2CO3/CoFe2O4, g-C3N4/CoFe2O4, g-C3N4/CoFe2O4, Bi2O2CO3 (BOC), CoFe2O4 (CF) and g-C3N4 (CN). The effect of operational parameters as effect of pH, H2O2, anions, ozone and peroxymonosulphate (PMS) was also studied. In BCBF + PMS + O3 + Vis protocol a spectacular complete degradation was observed in less than 30min. Ternary band structure efficiently
reduces the charge recombination rate and promotes spectral activity which was confirmed by photoluminescence, photocurrent response and EIS analysis. By LC-MS, scavenging experiments and ESR studies a possible mechanism was also proposed. Cyto-toxicity studies of degraded products on human peripheral blood cells revealed almost 99% cell viability affirming the complete mineralization. The junction was also used for reduction of 4-nitrophenol into 4- aminophenol with complete conversion in less than 5 min with rate constant 13.05 x 10 -3 s -1 . In addition the ternary junction shows a high visible powered conversion of CO2 producing CH4 (~119 µmol g -1 ), CO (~131 µmol g -1 ) and O2 (~242 µmol g -1 ) with a high rate constant of 13.05 x 10 -3 s -1 . Keywords: Solar; photodegradation; CO2 conversion; peroxymonosulphate; nanoheterojunction; carbon nitride
1. Introduction
Energy crisis, potable water shortage and environmental deterioration has aroused serious concerns worldwide in scientific and monitoring community [1-2]. Industrial development and agricultural dependence on pesticides, weedicides and herbicides has led to ecological crisis and affected human health. Herbicides contribute to a significant proportion of pollution caused by pesticides globally both in soil and water bodies. Paraquat (PQT) (1, 1-dimethyl-4, 4- bipyridylium dichloride) has been widely used as herbicide in agriculture from last 40 years [3]. Though banned in western countries it is still prevalent in developing economies. It possesses high toxicity which causes membrane damages in both, human and animals. Thus mineralization of PQT in wastewater is very essential factor to avoid aquatic pollution [4]. In addition, various reports claim that it causes health problems like Parkinson’s disease in humans [5]. It has a high aqueous solubility and a high resistance to hydrolysis which increases the chances of contamination. Removal of organic pollutants as paraquat from water is a challenging issue. Current processes as coagulation, flocculation, adsorption and biological oxidation suffer from various drawbacks because they do not completely remove the pollutant and are not cost effective [6]. Greener, faster and sustainable solution to removal of toxic persistent pollutants is of utmost importance. Advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) as photocatalysis [7-8], photoozonation [9], photo-fenton process [10] etc. and their combined operations have been significant in pollutant removal on lab-scale and industrial levels. This is because of higher degradation, greener approach, cost-effectiveness, lower toxicity and ease of performance [11, 12]. However
single photocatalysts suffer from serious drawbacks as limited spectrum capture, stability and electron-hole recombination [13]. Formation of hetero-junctions of semiconductors increases the photo-response, reduce the recombination and increase the catalytic activity manifolds. Recent years have witnessed the wide application of carbon based nanostructures in the field of photocatalysis, such as carbon nanotubes [14], fullerene [15], graphene oxide [16], reduced graphene oxide [17], and graphitic carbon nitride [2, 18]. Eco-friendly g-C3N4 is a low cost novel “metal-free” visible light induced semiconductor with a band gap 2.7 ev and stable under ambient conditions, both thermally and in solutions of pH 1-14 [19]. Meanwhile the photocatalytic performance of g-C3N4 is quite away from satisfactory due to its low surface area, high photogenerated charge recombination rate and low absorption efficiency (≥ 420 nm) in visible spectrum [20]. Many routes have been approached to overcome these problems such as designing nanotube structures [21], coupling with grapheme [22], hetero element doping [23] and construction of binary and ternary heterojunction etc. Various C3N4 based ternary heterojunctions have been designed as Ag/Fe3O4/g-C3N4 [24], g-C3N4/Ag/MoS2 [25] GQDs/PANI/g-C3N4 [26], MoS2/ZnO/C3N4 [27], g-C3N4/TiO2/rGO [28] etc. to boost its photocatalytic activity. Bismuth sub carbonate (Bi2O2CO3) having a sillen based structure [29] has received great attention because it displays promising photocatalytic activity for the degradation of organic pollutants as well as its non-toxic nature makes its utilization in pharmaceutical and medical field [30]. However the application of Bi2O2CO3 in photocatalysis is strongly limited by its relatively large band gap (3.2–3.4 eV). Several techniques have been developed to overcome these problems including doping [31] and fabrication with g-C3N4 [32] etc. Recently, cobalt ferrite (CoFe2O4) has been used in photocatalysis due to its ferromagnetism, narrow band gap, compatibility with living system, low cost and abundance in nature [33]. One of most exciting applications of superior semiconductor photocatalysts lies in photocatalytic conversion of CO2 into fuels and other valuable compounds [34]. The increasing levels of CO2 in the atmosphere due to various sources have led to global warming and climate change. The reduction of CO2 to yield CH4, CO, O2, and CH3OH etc. under ambient pressure and temperature has been done in recent years as an initiative for clean energy production [35-36]. Photocatalytic reduction of carbon dioxide has been promising but various researchers report lower yield or conversion as the reaction is complex [37]. Especially the conversion into syngas via CO
production is important [38]. Recent works report that effective charge separation, fixing of CO2 onto surface, band structure etc. are important for efficient conversion. Hence heterojunctions may play an eminent role. Biochar has been employed as a low cost support to various catalysts and nanomaterials especially in photocatalysis. Therefore by synthesizing biochar supported g-C3N4/Bi2O2CO3/CoFe2O4 nano-assembly we have attempted to steer the optical behavior, charge separation, stability, transportation, quantum efficiency to utilize for multi applications. The junction has been utilized for paraquat degradation, reduction of 4-nitrophenol into 4-aminophenol and visible reduction of CO2 2. Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Bismuth nitrate (Bi (NO3)3.5H2O), nitric acid, sodium carbonate (Na2CO3), hexadecyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB) ([N (CH₃)₃] + Br - ), urea, cobalt nitrate (Co (NO3)2.6H2O), ferric nitrate (Fe(NO3)3.9H2O), ethanol, paraquat (C12H14Cl2N2) were acquired from Sigma Aldrich (AR grade). Double distilled water was used in all the experiments.

sections.heading: 2.2 Preparation of graphitic g-C3N4 (CN)
sections.text: Typically 20 g of urea was calcined at 520 ° C for 4 h with the heating rate of 4 ° C min -1 in an electric kiln. After thermal condensation, the pristine mass of g-C3N4 was trodden into fine powder and thermally treated at 520 º C for 3 h in muffle furnace (Jupiter Scientific (CS-50b), Range up to 1200 ± 50 1ºC). The mass was then allowed to cool at room temperature. The product was then washed with ethanol & distilled water and dried at 80 º C in oven (Thermo Fisher Scientific, chamber material: Al, temperature range: +5 ºC to +220 ºC).

sections.heading: 2.3 Preparation of pruning waste (PW) derived biochar (PB)
sections.text:
Biochar was prepared from pruning waste of Prunus dulcis collected from fruit orchards in Himalayan region. The collected PW were chopped into small pieces, dried and powdered. The material was then sieved to get uniform size, as obtained powder was washed several times with distilled water and t dried overnight at 80 0 C. The raw mass was transferred into ceramic taped crucible and sintered at 400 °C for 3h in a muffle furnace under N2 atmosphere. The heating rate was 8 º C/min. The contents were then allowed to cool at room temperature and washed with distilled water and dried to obtain biochar.
2.3 Preparation of g-C3N4/Bi2O2CO3 (CB)
In the synthetic procedure 3g of bismuth citrate and 0.14g of urea were dissolved in 50 ml ethylene glycol. 0.1mM CTAB was added and ultrasonicated for 1h. The reaction mixture was then refluxed at 200ºC and centrifuged. The product obtained was washed with ethanol and distilled water. The black material was then sintered at 520 ° C for 4 h with the heating rate of 4 ° C min -1 in an electric kiln.

sections.heading: 2.4 Preparation of g-C3N4/Bi2O2CO3/ CoFe2O4 (CBF) heterojunction
sections.text: To 100 mL distilled water 0.5 g CTAB, 3 g Na2CO3 and 0.5 g of g-C3N4 were added. The mixture was stirred for 20 min followed by sonication for 1 h (Ultrasonicator- Frequency: 42 KHz, timer: digital timer, material: stainless steel with capacity 2.5L). After then a mixture of 1.712 g Bi (NO3) H2O and 10 mL HNO3 (1 mol L -1 ) was added drop wise under vigorous stirring for 2h. The precipitates were centrifuged and washed several times with deionized water/ethanol. Finally, the product (CB) was dried at 80 0 C for 24 h. 0.5g of above prepared product was then dispersed in 50 ml of distilled water. Then 0.2 M of ferric nitrate nonahydrate (25ml) was added to 0.1 M of cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (25ml) with stirring. The pH was adjusted to 11 with 1M NaOH. Finally the mixture was transferred to a teflon-lined autoclave and heated hydrothermally at 180 ᵒ C for 12 h. The resulting product was washed with double distilled water/ethanol and dried at 80 ᵒ C.

sections.heading: 2.5 Preparation of biochar templated g-C3N4/Bi2O2CO3/ CoFe2O4 (BCBF)
sections.text: BCBF was prepared by same route as reported for CBF. Initially 0.5g of biochar along with 0.500 g of CB was suspended in 50 ml of deionized water, stirred for 1h followed by sonication for 30 min and further rest of the procedure was same as mentioned in section 2.4.

sections.heading: 2.5 Characterization
sections.text:
The Fourier Transform Infra-Red (FTIR) spectrum of biochar, CBF and BCBF was obtained in range 4000 to 400cm -1 using Nicolet 5700 instrument. The phase purity and crystalline information was analyzed by X-ray diffraction (XRD, using a Rigaku X ray diffractometer with Cu Kαradiation. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed using a PHI 5000 Versa Probe spectrometer (ULVAC-PHI, Japan) with monochromatized Al Kα radiation. Specific surface area was analyzed using nitrogen adsorption-desorption on a NOVA 1200 analyzer and calculated using Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. The ultraviolet–visible spectra (UV–vis) were obtained using a Shimadzu 2202 double beam spectrophotometer. Photoluminescence (PL) was done using a fluorescence spectrophotometer (Hitachi, F-4600).
Magnetic studies were carried out using vibrating sample magnetometer (Microsense EV7, USA) up to field of 10,000 Oe. Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) H-7500 (JEM-1230 HC, Japan) was used to study surface morphology. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) imaging was done using a JEOL-2011 TEM instrument. Pzc determination and Electrochemical Impedance spectroscopic (EIS) measurements are given in supplementary information.
2.7 Photocatalytic setup for Paraquat (PQT) degradation under visible light (Xe lamp) and sunlight. For adsorptional removal, 50 mg of BCBF was added to 100 mL of 20 ppm solution of PQT in distilled water. The solution was kept in dark for adsorption. After regular intervals absorbance at 255 nm was recorded using spectrophotometer. The photocatalytic potential of prepared photocatalysts (single, binary and ternary) was investigated for the degradation of paraquat in water under artificial visible and natural sunlight illumination. For simulated solar light a visible light source in form of Xe lamp (800W) positioned in cylindrical quartz arrangement was used. The experimental set up is represented in Fig. S1. The detailed experimentation including the parameter variations, scavenging activity and reusability was studied for simulated conditions. The temperature was kept constant (30 ± 0.5 ºC) with water circulation in the photocatalytic reactor. The stock solution (100 ppm) of PQT was prepared in deionized/O2-saturated water. In a typical experimental protocol, photocatalyst (50mg) was suspended in 100 ml aqueous PQT solution (20 ppm) followed by stirring in dark for 30 min for adsorption-desorption equilibrium. The resulted suspension was then exposed to light source (Xe Lamp or sun). The concentration of paraquat was analyzed using HPLC( Shimadzu LC-10AD) equipped UV-Vis detector by employing a C-18 column (5 µm, 4.6 mm × 150 mm) and a diode array detector set at 250 nm. The eluent consisted of sodium hypophosphate and methyl cyanide in ratio 4:1 (v:v). The chemical oxygen demand (COD) was determined with a Nanocolor COD test which utilizes Ag-catalyzed oxidation with K2Cr2O7/H2SO4 for 2 h. Total organic carbon was determined by a TOC analyzer (Shimadzu, TOC-L) equipped with Shimadzu auto sampler. The limit of detection (LOD) was 0.5 mg/L. The degradation pathways were determined by detecting intermediates with a LC-TOF mass spectrometer with a electro spray ionization (ESI) and C18 column (150 mm x 2mm) (30:70 v/v methanol: water as mobile phase; 2% formic acid; injection volume 20µl.). Electron spin resonance (ESR) spectrum of spin-
trapped superoxide radical anions and hydroxyl radicals (for degradation under Xe lamp) was obtained using Bruker A200 spectrometer by trapping with 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline- N-oxide (DMPO). The effect of radical scavengers, nitrate ions, bicarbonate ions, ozone and peroxymonosulfate (PMS) on photodegradation of SME was also studied for experiments under Xe lamp. The degradation studies were also made under natural sunlight (month of May). The other experimental protocols include Vis + O3, solar + O3, vis + PMS, solar + PMS, vis + PMS + O3 and solar + PMS + O3. The experimental details for analysis of reactive oxygen species and reusability are given in supplementary data.

sections.heading: 2.8 Catalytic reduction of 4-Nitrophenol to 4-Aminophenol and photoreduction of CO2
sections.text: The experimental procedure for nitrophenol catalytic reduction and photoreduction of CO2 (Fig.S2) is given in supplementary information.

sections.heading: 2.9 Cyto-toxicity analysis
sections.text:
The cyto-toxixcity of the BCBF treated PQT contaminated water on Human peripheral blood lymphocytes (PBL) (Hi Media) was tested by MTT assay. The PBL cells were cultured in 10% RPMI-1640 medium and incubated overnight in 37°C. 10µl MTT was added into well (96 well plate) for generating formazan and again incubated for 4h. The crystal was then dissolved in 100 µl DMSO. The optical density was then measured using microplate reader (595 nm) and viability was calculated. The experiments were performed in triplicate.
3.1 Characterization 3.1.1 FTIR analysis Fig. 1 shows the FTIR spectra of BCBF, CBF and biochar. The spectrum of CBF shows typical internal vibration at 1068, 845, 1374 and 670 cm -1 which correspond to symmetric stretching mode ν1, corresponding anti-symmetric vibration ν2, the out of plane bending mode ν3 and the in-plane deformation ν4 respectively for bismuth oxycarbonate (BOC) [39]. The absorption peak for (ν1 + ν4) mode of the CO3 2− appeared at 1745 cm -1 and Bi-O stretching is observed at 540 cm -1 . For g-C3N4 (CN), strong absorption peaks appearing at 1200 to 1650 cm -1 which correspond to stretching mode of heterocyclic C=N and C-N. Furthermore the bands at 809 cm -1 [40] and 3204 cm -1
refer to the bending mode of heptazine unit and terminal NH2 or NH groups
of g-C3N4 aromatic rings respectively [41]. The two additional peaks appearing at high frequency 462 and 540 cm -1 , refer to Fe-O stretching mode. Further the FTIR spectrum of
BCBF revealed all the major peaks of BOC, CN and CF with slight shifting in wave numbers which may be due to bonding with biochar matrix. The peaks at 2919 and 2852 cm -1 correspond to (-CH2- stretching) alkyl moiety present on biochar surface. The pure biochar shows a broad band near 3650 cm -1 due the –OH stretching of polymeric compounds because of presence of cellulosic component of biochar [42]. The peaks at 1430 and 1036 cm -1 are for O-H bending or C-O stretching vibrations of phenolic moiety and polysaccharides components of biochar respectively.
3.1.2 XRD analysis Fig 2 shows the XRD patterns of BOC, CF, CN, CBF and BCBF. The diffractogram for CBF shows the characteristics peaks which can be indexed as, tetragonal Bi2O2CO3, inverse spinel CoFe2O4 and graphitic phase of C3N4, in CBF and BCBF which was matching well with standard JCPDS files no. 41-1488, 22-1086 [43] and 87-1526 respectively. For CBF the peaks which are appeared at 24.1 º , 30.52 º , 32.94 º , 42.56 º , 47.2 º , 57.16 º corresponding to (011), (013), (110), (114), (020), (123) planes of tetragonal Bi2O2CO3 [44]. Besides, the peak at 13.16 º and 27.36 º can be indexed to (100) and (002) plane of g-C3N4 respectively [45]. It can be noticed that there is a slight shift of peaks when compared to individual BOC, CF and CN because of formation of junction. Further the XRD pattern of CBF shows three phase composition due to hybridization of CoFe2O4 with Bi2O2CO3 and g-C3N4. Further the peaks at 30.5º, 35.5º, 42.5º, 53.5º, and 57.2º correspond to (111), (220), (400), (422), and (511) crystal planes of CoFe2O4 [46]. The XRD patterns of CBF exhibited overlap of characteristic diffraction peaks of individual components which confirmed the hybridization between them. Further the diffractogram of BCBF shows all the characteristics peaks of three components with slight up and down shift in 2θ value of respective component which might be due to the interaction of CBF with porous biochar matrix.

sections.heading: 3.1.3 SEM analysis
sections.text:
Fig. 3 shows the SEM micrographs of different resolutions for BCBF. The low resolution micrograph of BCBF (Fig. 3a) shows that semiconductor counterparts dispersed over the biochar matrix. Fig. 3(b) represents the high resolution interface of g-C3N4 (thin rough sheets), Bi2O2CO3 (flower shaped), CuFe2O4 (cubical crystals) and biochar (porous matrix) showing that junction is supported on biochar matrix. Fig. 3(c) shows the interface of g-C3N4 and porous biochar
structure. SEM image of the selected part of BCBF (Fig. 3d) shows the shape and structure of Bi2O2CO3 and CoFe2O4.
3.1.4 TEM, elemental and surface area analysis Fig. 4 shows the high and low resolution TEM images of BCBF. Low resolution images of BCBF (Fig. 4 a, b & c) reveal that the g-C3N4, Bi2O2CO3 and CoFe2O4 spread into biochar matrix and form an assembly. In Fig. 4(d) spherical/cubical ferrite and flower shaped Bi2O2CO3 nanoparticles in contact with porous graphitic carbon nitride sheets and biochar are clearly visible. Fig. 4d (inset) represents the SAED pattern which shows nearly crystalline nanocatalyst. Fig 4(e) shows the lattice fringes for Bi2O2CO3 and CoFe2O4 nanoparticles in contact with each other which are well matched with XRD findings. Fig 4(f) shows the corresponding elemental mapping for BCBF. The distribution of each element is given in Fig. 5(a)-(f). The surface area of BCBF was analyzed by BET N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms given in Fig. S3. The specific surface area of BCBF has been found to be 68.24 m 2 /g with pore size = 12.15nm and pore volume = 0.764 cm 3 /g.

sections.heading: 3.1.5 XPS analysis
sections.text:
The chemical state and surface composition of the elements in BCBF was investigated by XPS technique. Fig. S4 represents the XPS spectrum of BCBF showing the presence of C, N, Bi, O, Co, & Fe elements on the composite surface without other atom signal being detected. The deconvoluted spectra are shown in Fig. 6. The deconvoluted spectrum of C 1s (Fig. 6a) shows sharp peaks around 283.5 eV and 287.5 eV are attributed to the pure graphitic species in the CN matrix and carbon species from carbon contamination of XPS measurement and overlapping peaks of carbonate ion in Bi2O2CO3 & sp 2 -hybridized carbon in triazine rings (N-C= N) [47] respectively. The O 1s spectrum (Fig 6b) shows two peaks at 529.1 & 530.6eV referring to two types of oxygen attributed to oxides and the OH groups [48]. The peak for N 1 s (Fig. 6c) around 397.7 eV corresponds to sp 2 hybridized aromatic N bonded to carbon atoms C=N- C [49] and 398.5 & 400.3 eV corresponds to sp 3 N-C and C-NH respectively. Deconvoluted spectrum of Bi (Fig. 6d) shows two peaks at 163.6 and 158.3 which are ascribed to Bi 4f 5/2and Bi 4f 7/2 of Bi 3+ of Bi-O bond [50] respectively.
The corresponding Co 2p spectrum (Fig. 6e) exhibited two main peaks around 779.3 and 795.2 eV associated with the doublet Co 2p3/2 and Co2p1/2 regions respectively besides two relatively
less intense shake up satellite peaks around 785.1 and 802.9 eV. These observations prove the presence of Co 2+ species and practically exclude the existence of Co 3+ species at the composite surface. The deconvoluted Fe 2p spectrum (Fig. 6f) shows two main peaks at 710.1 and 724.7 eV, which are attributable to spin-orbit components, namely Fe2p3/2 and Fe2p1/2 for Fe 3+ oxidation state respectively.

sections.heading: 3.1.6 Magnetic and Optical studies:
sections.text:
The magnetic studies were made by VSM analysis of BCBF catalyst. Magnetization-Hysterisis (M-H) curve for BCBF is represented in Fig. 7(a). BCBF exhibits ferromagnetism with magnetization of 47.2 emu/g. The sample has enough magnetization for magnetic separation and recovery from aqueous medium. The optical properties of a material directly influence its photocatalytic activity. The UV-DRS spectra of photocatalysts are given in Fig.7 (b). The band gap plots are plotted according to Tauc relation [51]. Fig. 7(c) shows tauc plots for ternary and binary junctions. The values are listed in Table S1. The band gap of BCBF is 2.12 eV while that of CBF is 2.23eV. This may be ascribed to successful formation of hetero junction between the employed photocatalysts which not only expands the absorption spectrum but also reduces the charge recombination rate which is essential for photo-activity. The band gaps and band edges as calculated are listed in Table 1. Photoluminescence spectra of BCBF, CoFe2O4/Bi2O2CO3 (CF/BOC), g-C3N4/ Bi2O2CO3 (CN/BOC), g-C3N4/ CoFe2O4 (CN/CF) are given in Fig. 7(d). It is clear that g-C3N4/ Bi2O2CO3 shows a peak at about 425 nm, CoFe2O4/Bi2O2CO3 at 500 nm and g-C3N4/ CoFe2O4 at near 540nm. It is well known that higher the recombination rate, higher the PL intensity and lower the photocatalytic activity . All the peaks vanish in PL spectrum of BCBF, indicating that recombination of photogenerated charge carriers has fallen. This facilitates effective movement of charge carriers to the target.
The heterojunction with the locations of band edges and flow of charge carriers is represented in Fig. 8(a). There is an effective formation of a g-C3N4-Bi2O2CO3-CoFe2O4 junction supported on biochar matrix. When the three semiconductors are in contact to form junction (Fig. 8b), there is diffusion of electrons due to difference in Fermi levels. So electrons diffuse from g-C3N4 and CoFe2O4 from Bi2O2CO3. This results in accumulation of negative charges in g-C3N4 & Bi2O2CO3 and Bi2O2CO3 & CoFe2O4 close to junction. Simultaneously, holes get transferred from Bi2O2CO3 into g-C3N4 and CoFe2O4. Therefore, equilibrium is established and two intrinsic electric fields will also be generated at the interface. Under light exposure, electrons from CB of g-C3N4 get transferred to conduction band of Bi2O2CO3 (0.47eV) and from CB of CoFe2O4. 3.1.8 pzc determination, EIS analysis and Photocurrent response The surface charge density vs pH plot for BCBF is given in Fig S5. The point of zero charge was found to be 5.8 for BCBF. This shows that the surface of photocatalyst is negative above pH= 5.8 and positive below 5.8. The photocurrent responses of BCBF, CBF, CN/BOC, BOC/CF and CN/CF were studied using a three-electrode cell (Amperometric I vs t method) to confirm the separation efficiency of photo-generated carriers as observed in PL spectra. It can be seen in Fig. 7(c) that a steady photocurrent was generated (against Ag/AgCl) under visible light. The switching on of current was done after every 50 s and was repeated for 5 cycles. BCBF shows increase in photocurrent as compared to binary junctions which indicates that photogenerated charge carriers are well separated and recombination is reduced to high extent. The photocurrent behavior of the CBF is like that of CBF but to a smaller scale. This indicates that even biochar also plays a significant role in reducing recombination. The binary junctions are expected to have a lower photoactivity as compared to CBF and BCBF because of decreased photocurrent response. EIS spectra for BCBF, g-C3N4, Bi2O2CO3 and CoFe2O4 are given in Fig 7(d). The BCBF electrode reaches a steady state when compared to other singer photocatalysts. BCBF has a lower charge transfer resistance and has a small Nyquist semicircle. This shows that BCBF has a better conductivity and a higher separation of charge carriers [52]. This is also supported by the PL spectra.

sections.heading: 3.2 Adsorptional and photocatalytic degradation of PQT under Xe and natural sunlight
sections.text:
3.2.1 Adsorptional removal of PQT
The adsorptional potential of CBF and BCBF was tested by studying the adsorption of PQT. The results are given in Fig. 9(a) & (b). It is well established that adsorption plays an important role in removal of organic pollutants [53, 54]. Biochar has high adsorption potential because of hydroxyl, amino and carboxyl groups which leads to binding of the pollutant. And as expected, BCBF shows higher adsorption (60.5%) in 2h than CBF (31.2%). The overall adsorption follows Langmuir adsorption isotherm (Fig. 9b). Maximum adsorption capacity for BCBF is 371.74mmol/g and CBF is 195.23mmol/g. The RL values are favorable for Langmuir isotherm. The parameters are listed in Table S2. The higher adsorption capacity of BCBF is also supported by BET studies which reveal that BCBF has a high surface area.

sections.heading: 3.2.2 Photocatalytic degradation of PQT under visible irradiation (Xe lamp)
sections.text:
The efficiency of binary and ternary photocatalysts was investigated for the degradation of herbicide PQT under simulated solar light (Xe lamp) and natural sun light illumination. Plain photolysis of PQT under Xe lamp without photocatalyst was also tested (Fig. S6). Only 2.8% of degradation was observed which shows that PQT is highly stable and persistent pollutant. Under visible irradiation, we followed two protocols keeping in mind the higher adsorption potential. In first protocol the suspension of PQT + photocatalyst was kept in dark for 1h to establish adsorption-desorption equilibrium. The degradation results are given in Fig. S7 and pseudo first order kinetics are represented by Fig.S8. The initial pH of solution was 7.2. It was observed that 84.5% of PQT was removed in presence of BCBF and 52.1% in presence of CBF in a 2h experiment. The degradation under this protocol follows pseudo first order kinetics with rate constants 0.0321 min -1 (BCBF) and 0.242 min -1 (CBF). In second protocol the suspension was directly exposed to sunlight for adsorption and photo-degradation to occur simultaneously. Fig. 9(c) shows the degradation of PQT under second set of conditions. The total photo-degradation achieved for PQT in 90 min experiment in presence of BCBF and CBF was 99.3 and 79.5% respectively. The mechanism for radical generation is given in scheme S1.
Both BCBF and CBF show better results under direct exposure experiments. This is because when the suspension is kept for adsorption for 1h, the sites get occupied with the pollutant which limits the exposure of photocatalyst to light source. However in second condition, when the slurry is directly exposed to light, the adsorption and photo-degradation occur simultaneously. The pollutant is degraded as soon as it gets adsorbed. Thus the detailed experiments including parameter variation, scavenging, ozone, peroxymonosulphate (PMS), solar exposure, reusability
and toxicity studies were made for the second protocol. Fig. S9 shows the progressive lowering of absorbance maximum for PQT on degradation in presence of BCBF under direct exposure of Xe lamp. The overall degradation of PQT under this condition (simultaneous adsorption and photocatalysis) also follows pseudo first order kinetics. Fig. 9(d) shows the kinetic plots for all single, binary and ternary photocatalysts and the rate constants are listed in Table S3. It was observed that biochar templated g-C3N4/Bi2O2CO3/CoFe2O4 performs best under visible light than BOC/CF, CN/CF, CN-CF, CN/BOC, CF, BOC and CN.
The rate of degradation under visible light (Xe lamp) follows the following order:
BCBF (0.0689min -1 ) > CBF (0.0527 min -1 ) > BOC/CF (0.0286 min -1 ) > CN/CF (0.0266min -1 ) > CN/BOC (0.0248min -1 ) > CF (0.0136min -1 ) > BOC (0.0126min -1 ) > CN (0.0098min -1 )
The reaction is manifolds faster for BCBF as compared to single, binary and ternary photocatalysts. Comparing the BCBF and CBF, the former has higher activity because of lower band gap and higher adsorption potential of biochar which facilitates simultaneous adsorption and photocatalysis. It is a general fact that adsorbed pollutant is degraded faster than in bulk because the life time of reactive oxygen species is small. In addition, the fabrication of CBF with biochar can enhance the photocatalytic activity by promoting transfer of photogenerated electrons on the surface of CBF, by adsorbing pollutants on its surface and by expand light harvesting range by multiple scattering of light within the porous matrix [55, 56]. From Fig. 8 (a), it is observed that the electrons from the CB of the CN (-1.07 eV) migrate to the CB of CF (+0.70 eV) and BOC (+0.47 eV) because, the CB of CN is more negative than CB of CF and BOC. Secondly, the photogenerated electrons present in the CB of the BOC migrate to the VB of the CN and CB of CF as a result the electrons in the CB of the CN and holes in the VB of the BOC are efficiently separated. Third the holes in VB of BOC migrate to VB of CF and CN because the VB edge of CF (+1.96 eV) and CN (+1.35 eV) are less positive than BOC (+3.6 eV). Thus an efficient charge transfer occurs (accelerated by intrinsic electric field) throughout the ternary hetero-junction which leads to the excellent photocatalytic activity.

sections.heading: 3.2.3 Effect of operational parameters
sections.text:
To get deep insight into behavior of photocatalyst, pollutant and mechanism, effect of operational parameters onto degradation of PQT by BCBF was studied. Effect of H2O2, NO3 - ,
HCO3 - ions and pH was studied. H2O2 is an important oxidant in the photodegradation of organic pollutants. Effect of H2O2 in various dosages has been studied and results are given in Fig. 10(a). Addition of H2O2 leads to rapid degradation of PQT as it accelerates formation of hydroxyl radicals as it is better electron acceptor than oxygen [57]. When H2O2 undergoes irradiation it releases reactive oxygen species. The results show that with the increase in the concentration of H2O2 (0.5mM to 3mM) the degradation of PQT was significantly enhanced. Nearly 100% degradation was achieved in 45 min of exposure at high concentrations of H2O2. Thus reaction becomes multifold faster. H2O2 leads to the generation of more reactive ● OH radicals by self– decomposition, photolysis and accepting the free electrons generated during BCBF photo reaction. Therefore H2O2 scavenges more and more free electrons to provide ● OH radical for oxidative degradation of pollutant. The effect of commonly occurring inorganic ions as NO3 - and HCO3 - has been studied. Fig. 10(b) shows the degradation of PQT in BCBF+ NO3 - system. When NO3 - ions in different concentration (0.8mM to 5mM) were added to the reaction system the efficiency BCBF was remarkably increased. Nitrate ions act as major precursor for ● OH radicals under visible or solar light [58]. The degradation increases rapidly as nitrate concentration increases from 0.8mM to 3mM and 99.2% of PQT is degraded in just 45 min. However an inhibition effect was observed at 5mM conc. which may be due to the adsorption of NO3 - ion competing with PQT molecules on the surface of BCBF for active sites. The ion effect on mechanism is given in scheme S2. Fig. 10(c) shows degradation of PQT at varying concentration of HCO3 - ions (0.3 to 5mM). Some experiments have recorded that bicarbonate ions act as radical scavengers. The existence of HCO3 - ions in water cause alkalinity and may react with ● OH radical to generate ● CO3 - [59]. ● OH radicals are highly reactive but less selective as compared to ● CO3 - . In presence of BCBF + PQT system the rate is enhanced at lower concentrations. This is due to the fact that ● CO3 - ions have reactivity towards amino moieties [60] and PQT contains the amino functionality. However the functionality is quaternary one, so the pronounced effect is not observed. With high concentration of HCO3 - ions the rate falls due to increased scavenging of hydroxyl radicals as well as adsorption onto photocatalyst. Fig. 10(d) shows the effect of pH onto photo-degradation of PQT in BCBF + visible system. The highest degradation was observed in pH range 5-7 and falls at highly basic and acidic medium. To the best of our knowledge the pKa values of PQT are not known with absolute accuracy. However if we see the class of N-alkyl substituted pyridine derivatives, then pka values for them is 11 or
higher. Pzc of BCBF is 5.8 and working pH is 7.2. At this pH the surface of BCBF is –ve and that of PQT is +ve and this leads to strong electrostatic interaction between the two. At extremely low and high pH the degradation is inhibited due to repulsion between pollutant and photocatalyst.

sections.heading: 3.2.4 Scavenging experiments and ESR analysis
sections.text:
In order to confirm the existence of reactive species, radical trapping experiments were performed by using some sacrificial agents such as IPA (isopropyl alcohol), Na-EDTA (disodium ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid) and BQ (1,4-benzoquinone) which selectively scavenge HO • , h + and O2 •- respectively. Fig. 11 (a) shows the influence of scavengers on the photo-degradation of PQT by BCBF under Xe lamp irradiation. The degradation is reduced to 20.1% and 41.3% in presence of IPA and BQ respectively. This shows that •OH radicals are most active species but O2 •- also participates in the degradation. The ECB of g-C3N4 is -1.07 eV which is more negative than E o (O2/ • O - 2) = -0.33eV vs NHE [61]. Thus photogenerated electrons react with molecular oxygen to generate superoxide radical anions. However this is not true for the other two semiconductors (BOC & CF). Simultaneously the holes present in the high positive VB of Bi2O2CO3 (+3.6 eV) is high enough to oxidize H2O or - OH to HO • radicals as E o (•OH/ - OH) = 1.99eV vs NHE and E o (H2O/•OH) = 2.40eV vs NHE [62]. There is also a slight possibility of formation of •OH radicals from VB of CoFe2O4 (1.96eV). So from band junction studies it can be inferred that •OH have a higher probability of formation than •O2 - anions. The presence of the •OH radicals was also detected by reaction with terephthalic acid. As hydroxyl radicals attack the moiety, 2-Hydroxyterephthalic acid is formed. This is then confirmed by fluorescence at ~425nm (Fig. S10). After 10 min of visible exposure in presence of BCBF as photocatalyst the emission peak was observed which confirmed that hydroxyl radicals were formed. The intensity was then decreased because of degradation done by photocatalyst. Fig. 11(b) and (c) show the ESR spectrum of DMPO trapped •OH and •O2 - respectively taken after 20 min of exposure (Xe lamp). When exposed to light source a four-line ESR signal of DMPO-•OH with an intensity ratio of 1:2:2:1 was detected indicating the presence of •OH radicals (Fig. 11b). Also a four-line ESR signal with intensity 1:1:1:1 was detected for BCBF, which is characteristic of DMPO-•O2 - . A relatively weaker DMPO-•O2 - adduct signal shows that •OH radicals play a main role and •O2 - a lesser role. In the trapping experiments we observe that there is less effect of hole scavenging on PQT degradation, hinting that the hydroxyl radicals

The redox potential for E o (O2/H2O2) = -0.695eV and the ECB of g-C3N4 is -1.07 eV which means that there is a large probability of H2O2 formation which ultimately leads to hydroxyl radical formation. sections.heading: 3.2.5 Performance under solar light, ozone and peroxy monosulphate (PMS)
sections.text:
The potential of BCBF and binary photocatalysts was also utilized in degradation of PQT under natural solar light, photocatalyst + vis + PMS, photocatalyst + solar + PMS, photocatalyst + vis + O3 and photocatalyst + solar + O3 systems. For natural sunlight exposure: The area of experiment was Solan, Himachal Pradesh, India- 30.90ºN, 77.09ºE in the Western Himalayan region. The experiments were performed in the month of May with average intensity of sunlight as 31 × 10 3 ± 100 lx. The rest of conditions remain the same as in case of artificial visible light (Xe lamp). Fig. 12(a) shows reaction kinetics (pseudo first order) for photo-degradation of PQT in photocatalyst + solar light system. The rate constants and half-life times are listed in Table S3. The order of performance of photocatalysts under solar exposure is:
BCBF (0.0596min -1 ) > CBF (0.0369 min -1 ) > BOC/CF (0.0167 min -1 ) > CN/CF (0.0145min -1 ) > CN/BOC (0.0130min -1 ) > CF (0.0119min -1 ) > BOC (0.0109min -1 ) > CN (0.0076min -1 )
It is observed that under solar exposure, almost complete degradation of PQT is achieved but the
degradation time is delayed. In addition the rate is slower as shown by rate constants. This is due to the fact the solar spectrum contains UV, IR and visible light. In case of Xe lamp we have a pure visible irradiation. Thus the degradation is affected. Also the solar intensity is not consistent through the day and this may hamper the degradation process. However it is clear that the heterojunction can be used in real systems too. Fig. 12 (b) shows the degradation kinetics of PQT in presence of BCBF + PMS + vis/solar system. The overall degradation in presence of peroxymonosulphate follows pseudo-first order kinetics. The degradation is spectacular as complete removal of PQT was achieved in less than 45 min. The rate is higher in visible exposure than solar exposure.
The effect of PMS concentration on PQT degradation in BCBF + vis system was also studied. When 0.10 mM PMS is added, no pronounced effect is observed. However when concentration is increased to 0.1mM complete degradation is achieved in less than 45 min. The rate constant for degradation in case of 0.10mM PMS is 0.1020 min -1 with half-life of 6.794 min for visible exposure. The degradation was a slight slower in PMS (0.10 mM) + solar system with rate constant of 0.0912 min -1 . When PMS concentration is increased to 0.20 mM or 0.50 mM, only an incremental increase in PQT removal is observed. Hence 0.1mM concentration of PMS was selected for solar and ozonation experiments. The overall mechanism for PMS powered degradation is given in scheme S4. HSO5 - ions produce sulphate radical anions which lead to degradation of PQT. In addition presence of Fe and Co ions (in ferrite) may also react with HSO5 - ions to produce SO4 •- radicals. PMS initiated reaction is given in scheme S3. Quenching tests were performed by using ethanol and isopropyl alcohol (IPA) to differentiate between sulphate radical anions (SO4 •− ) from hydroxyl radicals (•OH) [63]. As shown in Fig. 12 (c) both ethanol and isopropyl alcohol diminish removal of PQT. Therefore both SO4 •− and •OH contribute to the removal of PQT in presence of PMS.
Further synergistic study was made by investigating the degradation of PQT in BCBF + vis + O3+ PMS (0.10 mM) and BCBF + solar + O3 + PMS (0.10 mM) systems. The results are given in Fig. 12(d) and rate constants in Table S4. The rate constant in visible exposure is 0.201min -1
and in solar irradiation is 0.143min -1 which is almost twice than in BCBF+ vis or BCBF + solar system. The half-lives show that degradation is extremely fast in this system. In presence of ozone a series of reactions [64] may take place as given in scheme S4. Even the superoxide radical anion would easily form hydroxyl radicals and SO5 •- would form SO4 •- via ozone. The photocatalytic activities also shows better results in the presence of O3 because the electron affinity of O3 (≈2.1 eV) is higher than that of O2 (≈0.44 eV) [65]. Fig. 13(a) shows the performance of various photocatalysts under Xe lamp and solar irradiation for PQT degradation in terms of rate constants. It can be observed that rate is almost 7 times higher than single photocatalysts. The comparison of rate constants for BCBF performance under various conditions is given in Fig. 13(b). We achieve highest rate for Vis+PMS+O3 system.

sections.heading: 3.2.6 Mechanistic way of degradation and TOC/COD analysis (under Xe lamp exposure)
sections.text: From scavenging experiments, band structure analysis and LC-MS analysis a proposed mechanism is predicted. Fig S12 (a) shows the reconstituted LC-MS spectrum of PQT after 20 min of degradation (in presence of BCBF) according to intermediates detected. The intermediates are listed in Table S5. Based on the intermediates detected (P1 to P6) and other experiments reported above proposed mechanism has been given in scheme S6. As explained earlier •OH radicals are major reactive species which attack the PQT molecule leading to ring opening (structure P1). Further hydrolysis leads to ring disruption to yield P2. After repeated attacks by hydroxyl radicals complete ring opening occurs (structures P3 & P5). The simpler aliphatic moieties further dissociate into lower molecular weight compounds and finally into N2, H2O, CO2 etc. Thus it is confirmed that mineralization of PQT takes place which is also confirmed by the CO2 emission detected using a Ca(OH)2 test. Further we analyze the total organic carbon (TOC) and chemical oxygen demand (COD) analysis of the degradation products. Fig. S12 (b) shows the TOC removal and % chemical oxygen demand of the solution analyzed after 3h of the exposure. 57.2% of TOC is removed in 3h experiment in presence of BCBF as photocatalyst and chemical oxygen demand decreases to 18.3%. This also confirms the degradation and mineralization.

sections.heading: 3.3 Catalytic Reduction of 4-NP into 4-AP by BCBF
sections.text:
Reduction of 4-nitrophenol (4-NP) into 4-aminophenol (4-AP) with NaBH4 in presence of BCBF was done to explore its catalytic activity. After adding NaBH4 solution to aqueous 4-NP, the color have been observed from in the solution from light yellow to dark yellow probably due to the formation of 4-nitrophenolate ion [66]. 4-NP shows a characteristic peak at about 315nm which shifts to 400nm after addition of sodium borohydride due to formation of 4-nitrophenolate ion. Fig. S15 shows the absorption spectrum of 4-NP without catalyst and Fig. S16 represents the spectrum with and without NaBH4. It shows there is no reduction possible in case of sole borohydride or sole catalyst. Fig. 15 (a) shows the absorption spectrum in presence of NaBH4 & BCBF. As the reduction reaction proceeds, the progressive lowering of absorption maxima at 400 nm takes place and a new absorption maximum was observed at 300 nm due to the formation of 4- AP. The isosbestic point approximately about 319 nm reveal the clean reduction of 4-NP to 4-AP without undergoing any side reaction. NaBH4 has been added in excess. This is to ensure that reduction follows a pseudo first-order kinetics with respect to 4-nitrophenol with no effect of NaBH4. The kinetics plots are given in Fig. 15 (b). The reaction follows first order kinetics with the order of catalysts as BCBF (13.05 x 10 -3 s -1 ) > Bi2O2CO3/CoFe2O4 (2.45 x 10 -3 ) > g-C3N4/CoFe2O4 (2.05 x 10 -3 s -1 ) > g-C3N4/ Bi2O2CO3 (1.40 x 10 -3 s -1 )
The high catalytic activity of BCBF is attributed to the fact that a higher amount of catalyst Bi2O2CO3/g-C3N4/CoFe2O4 is evenly dispersed or distributed over the biochar surface which provides better surface sites. However in case of other binary junctions as catalysts the agglomeration and lack of effective sites leads to a slower reaction. To further confirm the completion of reduction reaction LC-MS analysis of initial and final reaction mixture was carried out. The results are given in Fig. S17 (a) and (b). The base and fragments peaks show that there is a clear and clean conversion of nitrophenol into aminophenol.

sections.heading: 3.4 CO2 reduction
sections.text:
CO2 reduction (aqueous) was carried out in a reactor on exposure to simulated solar condition (Xe lamp) to further support the visible photo-catalytic activity of BCBF and other single photocatalysts. The gaseous CO2 is not to be dissolved in aqueous system, and almost negligible in pure water [67]. If suitable additives are added to the solution the solubility of CO2 and pH is greatly affected for effective reduction [68]. The nano-catalysts were analysed for CO2 reduction in an aqueous system without the help of any other co-catalyst. Fig. 15(c) shows the products evolved (CH4, CO & O2) by reduction of CO2 using BCBF as photocatalyst. CO was the major product in the experiment which is used in syngas. BCBF shows excellent activity by producing CH4 (~119 µmol g -1 ), CO (~131 µmol g -1 ), and O2 (~242 µmol g -1 ) in 8h experiment. A graphical representation of photoreduction of CO2 by BCBF is given in Fig. 15 (d). On irradiation electrons and holes are generated in semiconductors which bring about the reduction according to scheme S5. It has been reported earlier in literature that hydrogen evolution and CO2 reduction reactions often compete with each other in photocatalytic process [69]. However it is not possible to detect hydrogen concentration in very low concentrations in a gaschromatography column. It is easy to detect CO which is the major product. As in the experiment H2 has not been detected (which is due to its low amount produced), thus it can be assumed that H2O splitting was not competing with CO2 reduction. The parallel experiments were also done using CBF and other single photocatalysts i.e. CoFe2O4, g-C3N4 and Bi2O2CO3. The results are shown in Fig. S18 and Table S6. Comparing the performance of BCBF and CBF, ~86 µmol g -1
of CH4 was produced in presence of latter. The higher activity of BCBF is due to
following reasons: a lower band gap than CBF; dispersion of nano-junction on biochar matrix; better adsorption of CO2 onto photocatalyst due to affinity of biochar for CO2 and role of biochar
as a sink for electrons-reducing the recombination. Fig. S18 shows the comparative study of CH4 evolution by various photocatalysts. The order is: BCBF (~119 µmol g -1 ) > CBF (~86 µmol g -1 ) > CoFe2O4 (~28 µmol g -1 ) > Bi2O2CO3(~22 mol g -1 ) > g-C3N4(~9 µmol g -1 )
Fig. S19) shows the reusability of BCBF for CO2 reduction for five cycles. There is a negligible decrease in photoactivity.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text: In summary, novel magnetic BCBF heterojunction was fabricated with higher solar spectrum capture and spectacular photo-degradation activity under visible and natural sunlight. The biochar supported hetero-assembly is considered boost the quantum efficiency, charge separation, charge flow and generation of reactive oxygen species as revealed from PL, EIS and photocurrent response. BCBF was able to degrade 99.3 % of notorious herbicide PQT in 60 min of visible exposure with a high TOC/COD removal. In addition a remarkable 100% mineralization is achieved in BCBF+Vis+PMS+O3 system in less than 30min. The catalyst performs well under natural sunlight too. Radical trapping experiments and ESR studies show presence of •O2 - and •OH with dominance of latter one which was also supported by degradation of NBT and terephthalic acid. A mechanism for degradation has also been predicted. BCBF also exhibits higher catalytic activity for reduction of 4-nitrophenol into 4-aminophenol with a high rate constant of 13.05 x 10 -3 s -1 . The composite catalyst also shows a promising photo-reduction of CO2 into CH4. In addition adsorption of CO2 leads to higher conversion. The cyto-toxicity studies on human PBL cells reveal complete mineralization with safe water system. This lab scale work shows the significance of rationale designing of heterojunctions with an optimum contact interface structure for higher photoactivity which promises future ides focussing on engineering of photocatalysts for organic and environmental catalytic reactions.

metadata.abstractText: The development of novel visible powered nano-heterojunctions with multi-pronged capabilities for environmental and catalytic applications has been gaining importance for persistent pollutant degradation & clean energy production. A magnetically recoverable biochar supported ternary gC3N4/Bi2O2CO3/CoFe2O4 heterojunction (BCBF) was fabricated which shows a high visible photoactivity. The heterojunction was used for degradation of pesticide paraquat under visible radiation (Xe lamp), natural sunlight, photo-ozonation, peroxymonosulphate, and coupled conditions. A high degradation of 99.3% was achieved under visible radiation in 90 min and 92.1% under solar light in 120 min. Biochar supported ternary junction performs manifold faster than Bi2O2CO3/CoFe2O4, g-C3N4/CoFe2O4, g-C3N4/CoFe2O4, Bi2O2CO3 (BOC), CoFe2O4 (CF) and g-C3N4 (CN). The effect of operational parameters as effect of pH, H2O2, anions, ozone and peroxymonosulphate (PMS) was also studied.
